comment._content: I wonder who she was and what her life was like.

comment.author: 25136959@N07
comment._content: In response to your request for feedback - I view photos to help with my social history studies. I therefore depend on full and accurate captions - which are absent here. I do reciprocate by adding information where I have it but in this case i cannot help.

comment.author: 15856307@N03
comment._content: Is there any way to know at when that photo was taken?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Hi john8abalone and Misrsky, It's tough to help out here -- lantern slides often have very little identifying information on the labels. We typically transcribe it all, so what you see is everything we have. These slides were collected by our curator, W.H. Goodyear, in the early years of the 20th century. A survey of lantern slide collections lists T.H. MacAllister as 'active 1890s+' -- which gives you some idea of the date, though he could certainly have reproduced an earlier photograph. Deb Wythe, Digital Lab

comment.author: 25136959@N07
comment._content:
Thanks - that's interesting. The pose, hair, the make-up, the ornaments, the dress pattern and style are virtually timeless. You could see a woman looking just like this in many countries today. 

In western cultures in early days of photography the subjects tended to look straight at the camera and adopt quite a stern looking expression - presumably because of the length of exposure; but the effect is to give the impression that we were all stiff and starchy and pompous back in those days.

This woman looks natural, if a little shy  and rather demure - enigmatic might be the right word - striking certainly.
